title: Before 1 July 2016, will South Korea announce that the Terminal High-Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) missile defense system will be deployed on the Korean Peninsula?
preds: The latest:  China and Russia, as of June 29, continue to "urge the United States to back off, saying THAAD's deployment could also affect their security."
Roll-out of this system is going to require an official announcement, and would then take several days (or weeks). It cannot be deployed by tomorrow.

https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/271143 as pointed out by @Anneinak, " the military would make a final decision on the deployment of the U.S.-made advanced anti-missile system by the end of this year." Seems safe to forecast a zero chance of an announcement by tomorrow.

- United States and South Korea have begun talks on THAAD (29 June 2016).
- However, little more than 24 hours until "before 1 July" expires so likelihood question will be answered affirmatively is virtually nil.

Very probable that THAAD will be deployed, perhaps even over the coming months. It seems very unlikely that it is going to be deployed in the next couple of days, however, not least because finer points of the agreement that will facilitate this have yet to be worked out.
Most likely this won't happen before July 1, but here's the latest:
Everyone's busy with Brexit, and time has almost run out even as NK has sneaked in another missle test!!

Yonhap, June 24, 'U.S. says THAAD talks 'progressing well': http://english.yonhapnews.co.kr/national/2016/06/25/0301000000AEN20160625000400315.html
Clip from Yonhap article:
"Sources in South Korea have said that the THAAD talks have moved forward to a point where the two sides are now looking at candidate sites for deployment, including not only existing U.S. military bases but also mountainous areas away from cities."
Japan Today, June 24, 'Washington hopes to wrap up anti-missile deal with South Korea': http://www.japantoday.com/category/world/view/washington-hopes-to-wrap-up-anti-missile-deal-with-south-korea
UPI, June 24, 'Seoul: THAAD can intercept North Korea Musudan missiles': http://www.upi.com/Top_News/World-News/2016/06/24/Seoul-THAAD-can-intercept-North-Korea-Musudan-missiles/1941466774982/
Clips from UPI article:
"South Korea is responding to North Korea's recent launches of midrange ballistic missiles, and the solution is increasingly pointing to THAAD, the U.S. anti-missile defense system.
Seoul's Defense Minister Han Min-koo said in a statement issued Friday the deployment of THAAD in South Korea makes it possible to intercept incoming Musudan missiles, local news service News 1 reported."
The Nation, June 23, 'Kim says new missile can strike US Pacific bases': http://nation.com.pk/international/24-Jun-2016/kim-says-new-missile-can-strike-us-pacific-bases
Clips from Nation article:
“We can’t deny that (North Korea’s) technological development is making progress, and the situation is alarming,” Japanese government spokesman Koichi Hagiuda told reporters.
The North has publicly displayed an ICBM, called the KN-08, which uses the same engine technology as the Musudan but has never been test-fired.
Jeffrey Lewis, director of the East Asia Nonproliferation Program at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies in California, said the international community had to find a way to get Pyongyang to accept a missile test moratorium.
“If we do nothing, this ends in a successful flight test of the Musudan-based KN-08,” Lewis said."
Chances of an announcement within the next 9 days is highly unlikely, even with the recent double test. Sanctions are still the primary deterrent for the moment.  https://youtu.be/-m86H1ed4yw

One would have expected such an announcement at or shortly after the trilateral meeting of ROK, Japan and Sec. Def. Carter
The DOD  press release does not seem to indicate such an announcement is possible before July 1, 2016
U.S., Republic of Korea, Japan Trilateral Defense Ministers' Meeting Joint Press Statement
http://www.defense.gov/News/News-Releases/News-Release-View/Article/791223/us-republic-of-korea-japan-trilateral-defense-ministers-meeting-joint-press-sta
'The Secretary and the Ministers condemned in the strongest terms North Korea's recent provocative actions, including its fourth nuclear test and multiple ballistic missile launches as clear violations of United Nations Security Council resolutions. The Secretary and the Ministers affirmed the intention of the three countries to cooperate closely with one another and with the international community, to enforce United Nations Security Council resolution 2270. The three officials urged North Korea to refrain immediately from taking further actions that aggravate tensions and called on North Korea instead to focus on fulfilling its international obligations and commitments."
"The Ministers and the Secretary praised the close trilateral communication and cooperation that took place at various levels before and immediately following these incidents. They concluded that the three countries should continue these efforts by utilizing the current Defense Trilateral Talks (DTT) framework to enable rapid coordination among their respective defense authorities in the event of future North Korean threats or to address non-traditional security issues, such as humanitarian assistance and disaster relief"
"The Ministers and the Secretary discussed the upcoming trilateral missile warning exercise, PACIFIC DRAGON, which is to be conducted in accordance with the Trilateral Information Sharing Arrangement (TISA). The Secretary and the Ministers also decided to seek additional opportunities to promote trilateral defense cooperation, such as through defense medical related events and other cultural exchanges"
US DOD requested the authorization and appropriation back in 2015.http://comptroller.defense.gov/Portals/45/Documents/defbudget/fy2016/budget_justification/pdfs/02_Procurement/MDA_PROCUREMENT_MasterJustificationBook_Missile_Defense_Agency_PB_2016_1.pdf
No authorization or appropriation I can find by US Congress.
Per Korea Times:
http://www.koreatimesus.com/seoul-washington-discussing-location-of-thaad-deployment/
(June 6, 2016)
"SEOUL, (Yonhap) — South Korea and the United States are discussing the possible location of the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) system that could be deployed in the country to deter North Korea’s ever growing missile threats, military sources said Monday"
"According to sources, the possible candidates for the base of the THAAD system includes U.S. military bases in the southern city of 
Daegu or Pyeongtaek, some 70 kilometers south of Seoul"
*     *    *
"Another insider with knowledge on the matter said it is reviewing the feasibility of all candidate locations but said it has not yet narrowed down sites".
*    *    *
Military pundits expect the decision to be made before the Security Consultative Meeting slated for October.
   *    *    *
Seoul and Washington have been refraining from making detailed statements on the deployment of the THAAD system, especially as China has been expressing discontent against the move, claiming that it could be used against Beijing.
Ever less likely as time goes by.

NK News, June 7, 'S.Korea ‘undoubtedly’ intends to deploy THAAD: defense minister - THAAD becomes political, diplomatic issue as China-U.S. competition in Asia-Pacific heats up': https://www.nknews.org/2016/06/s-korea-undoubtedly-intends-to-deploy-thaad-defense-minister/
Clips from NKN article:
"Seoul’s defense minister reiterated the necessity for THAAD in South Korea during an interview after his speech at the Shangri-La dialogue in Singapore, despite objections from China.
Defense Minister Han Min-koo didn’t mention THAAD deployment during his speech on Saturday, but said that South Korea “undoubtedly has the intent to deploy THAAD,” during the Q&A session.
One expert said THAAD is inevitably a political and diplomatic issue regardless of the military usefulness.
“The U.S. wants to expand its influence in Asia and China wants to increase its presence in the Pacific Ocean. Now the conflict in the South China Sea is expanding to the Korean Peninsula,” Kim Dong-yup, professor at Seoul’s University of North Korean Studies told NK News."

Breaking Defense, June 2, 'US Won’t Back Off On Korean Missile Defense, South China Sea: SecDef': http://breakingdefense.com/2016/06/us-wont-back-off-on-korean-missile-defense-south-china-sea-secdef/?utm_source=hs_email&utm_medium=email&utm_content=30227356&_hsenc=p2ANqtz-97BiEqow4OlNiZbgzJL6m2VfOVYhVgnYJ-NEjTbw7bH_hJODpenCUS8wqlD8BtOVSYmIZFGdLJDlwgd3TzMqyybIhV5g&_hsmi=30227356
Clips from the BD article:
"But, asked one reporter, don’t five North Korean missile tests in a row (albeit all failures) call for a reappraisal of the threat?
“Whatever the outcome of the test, the fact remains that they’re trying to make those missiles fly,” said Carter. “Whatever the outcome, this is something that is provocative. It’s destabilizing. It’s contrary to the United Nations Security Council resolutions.”
It’s this missile threat that seems to have finally convinced South Korea to ask for an American THAAD battery, supplementing shorter-range Patriot missile defense systems. (Both are US Army systems, underscoring the often-overlooked role of land power in the Pacific). Carter will meet in Singapore with his South Korean counterpart, he said, and “I’m sure that topic will come up, (but) it’s not something we need to discuss much…because the plans are moving forward.”
“This is an alliance decision, a decision of the United States and the Republic of Korea which is about protecting us both from North Korean missile attack,” Carter said. “It’s an alliance decision, (and) the implementation of it will be a series of decisions that we take together.”
“There are a lot of technical issues to get through,” a senior defense official elaborated — a phrasing which implies the political and strategic issue of whether to deploy THAAD is settled and now it’s just a question of how. “We will have a public announcement soon, but I’m not in a position to give you exact timing.”

July is close at hand, so lowering estimate.
With the continued missile failures, some pressure for THAAD introduction has been lifted. My guess is that behind the scenes there is a delicate balance between exercising the THAAD deployment and waiting to see if China is carrying through on economic sanctions against DPRK. The backdrop to all this is the complexity of the South China Sea challenges. Obama has generally shown a tendency to try to compartmentalize issues that are naturally intertwined. If China fails to live up to its sanction commitments, then there is less reason to hold off on THAAD. It also could be that the US is simply trying to dial down the overall temperature of the US_China relations, knowing that  the UN Arbitration ruling is coming shortly and the chance of a military casualty is rising.

There will be a deployment. Right now Kim III keeps launching and testing. As the volley continues, there is more than a likelihood, it's a certainty. But not now while the parties await the impact of sanctions. 
South Korea values it's relationship with Russia as well as PRC.
For now. President Park has Patriot deployment in front of ROE defense ministry. 
Short of a near miss, I would expect THAAD deployment as DPRK tests continue, A miss is as threatening as a launch pad accident as a volley over Japan, DPRK threat will force THAAD deployment.
ROK requires  DPRK de nuclearization before direct talks.

But they only push the North if they have very clear support and backing from the U.S which is not very likely at the moment, given all the other stuff the U.S. has on it's plate right now. If Trump wins though the odds become much higher.

"A U.S. senator proposed Thursday that next year's defense budget bill include calls for deployment of the THAAD missile defense system in South Korea to beef up defense against growing nuclear and missile threats from North Korea."

During or directly after the end-of-June missile practice, it is not out of the question that we'll hear an announcement like, "We've been a-studyin' on it, and we reckon we'll be gittin' that thar THAAD system right soon.  Ma'am."

More recent article on RIMPAC-2016:
The Diplomat, May 23, 'South Korea, Japan to Hold Missile Defense Drill in June': http://thediplomat.com/2016/05/south-korea-japan-to-hold-missile-defense-drill-in-june/
Clips from article:
"South Korea, U.S. and Japan have held joint search and rescue drills numerous times in the past, but this marks the first time we hold a missile warning exercise,” a high-ranking official of Seoul’s Defense Ministry told The Korea Herald. “The drill is confined to the framework of the trilateral information sharing pact (on Pyongyang’s nuclear and missile capabilities) and is not a strategic exercise.”
“One Aegis-level vessel from each country,” will participate in the drill a South Korean defense official told CNN, which will involve “detecting and tracing a hypothetical North Korean missile.” However, it will not involve the interception of the missile. (A military fighter jet will stand in for the missile.)
The exercise will focus on acquiring and sharing intelligence between the three countries “because of the limitations of the information-sharing pact,” a South Korean defense official said. South Korea, Japan and the United States signed an intelligence-gathering pact in 2014 to respond to North Korea’s growing missile threat.
“To hold such drills has been decided to better defend South Korea from ever-increasing nuclear and missile threats from North Korea and detailed plans have been worked out,” the South Korean defense official said. However, the South Korean defense ministry emphasized that the drill will have ”nothing to do with any country’s missile defense program.”

reaffirming 0%.  A THAAD deployment to South Korea indicates a failure of liberal diplomacy with China and other Asian nations.  If THAAD is deployed this will be a big pivot away from liberalism towards Realism.  I'm not convinced this is the legacy President Obama wants to leave behind.  I think most of the THAAD rhetoric over the last few months is really the US telling the world "is this really what you want?"  It's what Russia wants I'm not sure if China is ready for this especially considering changing macroeconomics.  Feel free to punch holes in my reasoning.  :)

NK has appointed a new Foreign Minister (according to Reuters). NK says it does not mean a change in policy. The new man was the the negotiator  for the last 6 nation disarmament talk. This might indicate that NK just wants to try to add some uncertainty to its foreign relations hoping that countries will soften the application of the agreed sanctions while they find out what the new Foreign Minister has to say. In turn this may pause any moves toward THAAD in SK. Of course linked to the likelihood of a THAAD in SK are provocative acts by NK.  The last missile and nuclear tests were down played by the US and SK so presumably they do not want to increase tension. The US, Japan and SK are reported to be holding  joint exercises in tracking NK missiles off Hawaii in late June. Together these reduce the likelihood of a THAAD announcement  about deployment in Korea before 1 July.
I feel I should update in view of upcoming US/SK/Japan missile defense exercises [1].

An announcement is not a deployment, and you can whip up an announcement pretty fast if you've already been drafting one anyway.  Such a deployment would have stiff expenses and very limited tactical or strategic value, but announcements are cheap and useful for signalling. I would never say a zero probability of anything before some date, but it appears to be approaching zero. I think the Obama administration is more likely to use the potential for THAAD as a diplomatic tactic to reengage nuclear negotiation talks, so I don't see a rush to deploy. It may be deployed later, but probably not by 1 July 2016.

Ms. Park is quite determined to have THAAD deployment and I believe that the national assembly debacle will not hold her back.  And talks are progressing quite nicely.  Really, it is now coming down to negotiation of location.  Not much between today and announcement of agreement.  Not quite sure that enough to trigger an affirmative, and we have little time here.  So for now, I am going just over consensus.

THAAD is an interesting solution to a poorly defined problem. The threat to South Korea is in the form of Low Trajectory Missiles and short flight submarine launched ordnance. It is Japan that would most benefit from a THAAD SYSTEM DEPLOYED ON THE Korean peninsula. I think this group is well aware of the state of relations between Korea and Japan. "Each of the parties has a different set of calculations. While both President Park Geun-hye and Saenuri Party leader Kim Moo-sung are staunch supporters of holding deliberations about THAAD deployment - which they think is the “obvious” choice - they appear to have concluded that growing controversy, including a backlash in areas where the system might be deployed, will not help in the general elections.
The Minjoo Party, led by Kim Jong-in, has not clearly stated whether it supports or opposes THAAD deployment. The wait-and-see attitude that Kim has taken - he has called for a “cool assessment” of the THAAD deployment - appears related to his election strategy of not focusing on security issues.
While both the Saenuri Party and the Minjoo Party made no mention of THAAD deployment in their platforms, they both promised to develop a Korea Air and Missile Defense system.
People‘s Party leader Ahn Cheol-soo has responded to questions about THAAD by arguing that “a popular consensus should be achieved through public discussion.”
The Justice Party is the only party with seats in the National Assembly that has expressed its opposition to deploying THAAD. During the press conference at which it announced its campaign platform, the party denounced President Park’s support for THAAD as an “arbitrary hardline response.”

There are good reasons to employ the THAAD system in South Korea: as a deterrent to the Norths missiles, as a ways to bring pressure on the North from China, and The current Prime Minister of the South looks as if she is tired of the threats from the North and may allow the system to call their bluff.  The big drawback is the Chinese do not like the idea of the THAAD in the south.  The Chines do not necessarily object to the systems ability to shoot down missiles as much as they object to the radars ability to conduct surveillance on Chinese systems.  This data would assist us in building tracking points for Chinese missiles, which the Chinese would like to keep secret.

Neither China nor Russia want THAAD deployed in the region. If it's not a bright-red line, then at least it is sunlit. Both Russia and China see THAAD as a step to decrease their missile capabilities (regardless of THAAD's original design).
